steps.text: Stay calm and note the time: Start timing the seizure immediately. Duration is critical information for EMS. Most seizures last 30 seconds to 2 minutes
Protect from injury: Clear away furniture, sharp objects, anything hard. If standing, guide person gently to floor. Place something soft under their head
Do NOT restrain: Never hold the person down or try to stop the movements. This can cause injury. The seizure must run its course
Do NOT put anything in mouth: The person cannot swallow their tongue. Putting objects in mouth can break teeth, injure jaw, or cause choking
Turn on side (recovery position): Once convulsions stop, turn person on their side. This keeps airway clear and allows fluids to drain. Tilt head back slightly
Call 911 if: Seizure lasts more than 5 minutes, person doesn't regain consciousness, another seizure follows, person is injured, pregnant, or diabetic, or this is their first seizure
Stay until fully alert: Person may be confused, sleepy, or agitated after seizure (postictal state). Stay calm, speak softly, explain what happened. Do not give food/water until fully alert
Loosen tight clothing: Undo collars, ties, belts. Check breathing regularly. If breathing doesn't resume after seizure stops, begin CPR

name: Febrile Seizure
description: Seizure in children caused by fever

steps.text: Stay calm - most febrile seizures stop on their own
Place child on side on safe surface
Do not restrain or put anything in mouth
Time the seizure
Call 911 if seizure lasts more than 5 minutes
After seizure, cool child gradually and see doctor

name: Stroke
description: Brain attack - use FAST to identify

steps.text: Use FAST assessment: F-Face drooping (ask to smile, is one side drooping?), A-Arm weakness (ask to raise both arms, does one drift down?), S-Speech difficulty (slurred, confused, unable to repeat simple phrase?), T-Time to call 911
Call 911 immediately: State 'possible stroke.' Time is critical - there is a narrow window for clot-busting treatment. Every minute matters for brain survival
Note the exact time symptoms started: This is crucial information. Treatment options depend on how long since symptom onset. Ask bystanders if you didn't witness it
Keep person still and calm: Have them lie down with head slightly elevated (15-30 degrees). Turn on side if vomiting. Do not allow them to walk or move unnecessarily
Do NOT give anything by mouth: No food, water, or medications (including aspirin - unlike heart attack, stroke may be a bleeding not a clot). Person may have difficulty swallowing
Loosen restrictive clothing: Undo collar, tie, bra, belt. This helps with breathing and blood flow. Keep person comfortable but still
Monitor breathing closely: Stroke can affect breathing. If person becomes unresponsive and stops breathing normally, begin CPR immediately
Note all symptoms: Record what you observe - weakness on which side, speech problems, vision issues, confusion level. This helps medical team assess and treat
Help person lie down with legs elevated
Loosen tight clothing
Check for breathing and pulse
If they don't regain consciousness in 1 minute, call 911
When conscious, have them stay lying down for several minutes
Give water when fully alert
